required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Active Dads Healthy Families: Promoting Physical Activity and Enhancing Father-child Relationships Through Parks and Recreation

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the feasibility of implementing a community-delivered physical activity program for fathers and their children ages 2-5 years.

detailed_description.textblock: The investigators will evaluate the feasibility of a community-based father-child physical activity promotion program. The investigators will work with a local Parks and Recreation department to recruit and deliver programming to three cohorts of fathers and their children 2-5 years old. To evaluate program feasibility, the investigators will assess recruitment efforts, program attendance, and participant engagement and satisfaction with the program. The investigators will also assess change in father-child outcomes post program including objectively measured physical activity, fathers' parenting, and father involvement.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: A non-randomized quasi-experimental design will be used to evaluate the feasibility of the Active Dads Healthy Families intervention, and provide preliminary data of changes over time and between three forms of the intervention. The investigators will recruit three cohorts totaling 45 father-child dyads (15 per cohort) to take part in the 8-week program delivered by Parks and Recreation. The primary outcome is program feasibility.

primary_outcome.measure: Recruitment as measured by number of participants who enroll
Attendance as measured by number of participants present at each session
Degree of participation in physical activity during each session
primary_outcome.description: As measured by observation using the System for Observing Fitness Instruction Time (SOFIT) instrument, activity scores range from 1 "lying down" to 5 "vigorous"

primary_outcome.measure: Percent of participants satisfied with the program as measured by self-report evaluation survey
primary_outcome.description: Self-report program evaluation survey; 13 items with responses ranging from 1 "strongly disagree" to 5 "strongly agree"

primary_outcome.measure: Percent of participants who complete all study measures
Percent of participants who complete all study measures

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in moderate to vigorous physical activity as measured by accelerometry
Change in moderate to vigorous physical activity as measured by accelerometry
Change in father support for child physical activity as measured by father self-report
secondary_outcome.description: 15-item engagement subscale score from the Preschool Physical Activity Parenting Practices instrument, scored by calculating mean of items (range 1-5), higher scores indicate greater parent engagement

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in father physical activity psychological control as measured by father self-report
secondary_outcome.description: 5-item psychological control subscale score from the Preschool Physical Activity Parenting Practices instrument, scored by calculating mean of items (range 1-5), higher scores indicate greater parent psychological control

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in father involvement in physical play as measured by father self-report
secondary_outcome.description: 9-item scale about father involvement in physical play, scored by calculating the mean of all items (range 1-6), with higher scores indicating greater father involvement

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in father involvement in care-giving as measured by father self-report
secondary_outcome.description: 13-item scale about father involvement in care-giving, scored by calculating the mean of all items (range 1-6), with higher scores indicate greater father involvement

arm_group.arm_group_label: Active Dads Healthy Families: Outdoor Education
arm_group.description: The intervention will include outdoor education and physical activity opportunities at various outdoor parks. The program will be held one day a week for eight consecutive weeks. Parks and Recreation will facilitate and run the program. Each session will last 60 minutes and include a brief educational discussion and opportunities for various games and activities. Each session will have a special theme relevant to the outdoors. Families will also receive a home toolbox to facilitate activity and learning outside of the program. Feedback on physical activity will be provided at the beginning and the end of the program.

The intervention will include physical activity opportunities at a community center. The program will be held one day a week for eight consecutive weeks. Parks and Recreation will facilitate and run the program. Each session will last 60 minutes and include a brief educational discussion and opportunities for various games and activities. Families will also receive a home toolbox to facilitate activity outside of the program. Feedback on physical activity will be provided at the beginning and the end of the program.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Active Dads Healthy Families: Fitness + Parenting
arm_group.description: The intervention will include physical activity opportunities and social support for fathers at a community center. The program will be held one day a week for eight consecutive weeks. Parks and Recreation will facilitate and run the program. Each session will last 60 minutes and include a brief educational discussion and opportunities for various games and activities. Families will also receive a home toolbox to facilitate activity outside of the program. Feedback on physical activity will be provided at the beginning and the end of the program.

intervention.arm_group_label: Active Dads Healthy Families: Fitness + Parenting

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Father or father figure to child between the ages 2-5 years
- Father or father figure 18+ years
- Can speak and read in English
Exclusion Criteria:
- Father or child has a physical disability precluding them from being physically active
